raw_text: There is a number of corpora annotated for the presence of topical shifts by one or more annotators. Passonneau and Litman (1997) describe an experiment where seven untrained annotators were asked to find discourse segments in a corpus of transcribed narratives about a movie
clean_text: Passonneau and Litman (1997) describe an experiment where seven untrained annotators were asked to find discourse segments in a corpus of transcribed narratives about a movie.

raw_text: We turned the segmentation task into a classification task by using boundaries between dialogue acts as one class and non-boundaries a the other (see Passonneau and Litman (1997) for a similar practice)
clean_text: We turned the segmentation task into a classification task by using boundaries between dialogue acts as one class and non-boundaries a the other (see Passonneau and Litman (1997) for a similar practice).

raw_text: By using multiple markers and machine learning methods, topic segmentation algorithms may be developed using this second approach that have a higher accuracy than methods using a single marker alone (Passonneau and Litman, 1997)
clean_text: By using multiple markers and machine learning methods, topic segmentation algorithms may be developed using this second approach that have a higher accuracy than methods using a single marker alone (Passonneau and Litman, 1997).

raw_text: Even annotating linear segmentation is challenging, particularly in the vicinity of segment boundaries (PassonneauandLitman, 1997)
clean_text: Even annotating linear segmentation is challenging, particularly in the vicinity of segment boundaries (PassonneauandLitman, 1997).

raw_text: These referential and lexical features build on the work of Passonneau and Litman (1997), who use them in discourse segmentation
clean_text: These referential and lexical features build on the work of Passonneau and Litman (1997), who use them in discourse segmentation.

raw_text: First, if non-canonicals are indicators of attentional stack pops, they should be more likely at segment boundaries; hence, we expect an increased presence of cue words (Passonneau and Litman, 1997) on non-canonicals compared to canonicals
clean_text: First, if non-canonicals are indicators of attentional stack pops, they should be more likely at segment boundaries; hence, we expect an increased presence of cue words (Passonneau and Litman, 1997) on non-canonicals compared to canonicals.

citing_paper_authors: Milan, Tofiloski | Julian, Brooke | Maite, Taboada
raw_text: In this sense, we are performing low-level discourse segmentation, as opposed to segmenting text into chunks or topics (e.g., Passonneau and Litman (1997))
clean_text: In this sense, we are performing low-level discourse segmentation, as opposed to segmenting text into chunks or topics (e.g., Passonneau and Litman (1997)).

citing_paper_authors: Fan, Yang | Peter A., Heeman | Andrew, Kun
raw_text: In spontaneous monologue, Butterworth (1972) found that the beginning of a discourse segment exhibited slower speaking rate; Swerts (1995), and Passonneau and Litman (1997) found that pause length correlates with discourse segment boundaries; Hirschberg and Nakatani (1996) found that the beginning of a discourse segment correlates with higher pitch
clean_text: Passonneau and Litman (1997) found that pause length correlates with discourse segment boundaries.

citing_paper_authors: Weiqun, Xu | Bo, Xu | Taiyi, Huang | Hairong, Xia
raw_text: This makes it different from others using surface features like (Passonneau and Litman, 1997)
clean_text: This makes it different from others using surface features like (Passonneau and Litman, 1997).

raw_text: Automatic discourse segmentation, as shallow annotation of discourse structure, also provides a testing grounds for linguistic theories of dis course (Passonneau and Litman, 1997) and provides a natural unit of measure in linguistic corpora (Biber et al, 2004)
clean_text: Automatic discourse segmentation, as shallow annotation of discourse structure, also provides a testing grounds for linguistic theories of discourse (Passonneau and Litman, 1997) and provides a natural unit of measure in linguistic corpora (Biber et al, 2004).

raw_text: Human annotators demonstrate frequent disagreement about the number of segments and exactly where the transitions between segments occur, while still demonstrating statistically significant agreement (Passonneau and Litman, 1997)
clean_text: Human annotators demonstrate frequent disagreement about the number of segments and exactly where the transitions between segments occur, while still demonstrating statistically significant agreement (Passonneau and Litman, 1997).
